title: Cross-Text Connections
subtitle: Analyzing Relationships Between Texts
learning_objectives: Compare and contrast different authors' perspectives
Analyze how texts build upon or challenge each other
Master College Board's cross-text question strategies

content.heading: Learning Objectives
content.text: In this lesson, you'll master analyzing relationships between multiple texts - a key skill for understanding how different authors approach the same topic.
bullet_points: Learn to identify different types of text relationships
Master comparison and contrast techniques for paired passages
Practice analyzing how authors build on or challenge each other's ideas
Apply systematic strategies for cross-text questions

content.heading: What Are Cross-Text Connections?
content.text: Cross-text connections involve analyzing how two or more texts relate to each other when discussing similar topics, themes, or issues.
main_points: Texts may agree, disagree, or present different aspects of the same topic
Authors may use different evidence to support similar conclusions
One text may provide context or background for another
Texts may represent different time periods, perspectives, or approaches
relationship_types: Agreement: Both texts support the same position with different evidence
Disagreement: Texts present opposing viewpoints or contradictory evidence
Complementary: Texts focus on different aspects of the same topic
Sequential: One text builds on or updates information from another
Contextual: One text provides background for understanding another

content.reveal_text: College Board Focus: Questions test your ability to see relationships between texts, not just understand each text individually.

strategy_steps.description: Identify the main topic and purpose of each text
Note each author's main argument or position
Look for areas of agreement and disagreement
Identify different types of evidence each author uses
Determine the overall relationship between texts
Select the answer that best describes the relationship
Verify your answer against both texts

content.scenario: Topic: The benefits of reading physical books vs. digital books
content.text_a_summary: Text A: Argues that physical books provide better comprehension and retention. Cites studies showing 20% better recall with print books and discusses the importance of tactile experience in learning.
content.text_b_summary: Text B: Acknowledges that print books have advantages but emphasizes digital books' accessibility features, environmental benefits, and cost-effectiveness. Notes that comprehension differences decrease with practice.
content.question: How would you describe the relationship between these texts?

walkthrough.question: What is each text's main position?
walkthrough.answer: A: favors physical books for comprehension; B: balanced view favoring digital for practical reasons

walkthrough.question: Do they completely disagree?
walkthrough.answer: No - B acknowledges A's points about comprehension advantages

walkthrough.question: What's the overall relationship?
walkthrough.answer: Nuanced disagreement - B acknowledges A's points but argues other factors outweigh them

content.instructions: Read these text summaries and identify their relationship using the CONNECT method.
content.scenario: Topic: The role of artificial intelligence in education
content.text_1: Passage 1 discusses how AI tutoring systems can provide personalized learning experiences, adapting to individual student needs and providing instant feedback. The author presents data showing 30% improvement in math scores.
content.text_2: Passage 2 examines potential risks of AI in education, including reduced human interaction, privacy concerns with student data, and the risk of over-dependence on technology for learning.
content.question: Which best describes how Passage 2 relates to Passage 1?
content.strategy_tip: Use CONNECT: Compare purposes, Outline positions, Notice agreements/disagreements.

options: Passage 2 completely contradicts Passage 1's claims about AI effectiveness
Passage 2 provides additional evidence supporting Passage 1's arguments
Passage 2 presents important concerns that balance Passage 1's optimistic view
Passage 2 discusses an entirely different aspect of AI that doesn't relate to Passage 1
content.explanation: Passage 2 doesn't contradict the effectiveness data from Passage 1, but presents important counterbalancing concerns (human interaction, privacy, over-dependence) that provide a more complete view of AI in education.

content.heading: Mastering Complex Text Relationships
content.text: Learn to handle sophisticated cross-text scenarios involving multiple perspectives, historical contexts, and evolving ideas.

advanced_patterns.description: Texts show how understanding has evolved over time
advanced_patterns.example: Text 1: 1990s view of internet privacy; Text 2: Current perspective after social media emergence

advanced_patterns.description: Different fields examine the same phenomenon
advanced_patterns.example: Text 1: Economist's view of remote work; Text 2: Psychologist's view of remote work
advanced_patterns.key_clues: Different types of evidence, methodologies, terminology

advanced_patterns.description: Texts examine different scales of the same issue
advanced_patterns.example: Text 1: Individual impacts of climate change; Text 2: Global policy responses
advanced_patterns.key_clues: Individual vs. collective focus, micro vs. macro perspectives

advanced_patterns.description: Texts present different approaches to solving the same problem
advanced_patterns.example: Text 1: Technology solutions to traffic; Text 2: Urban planning solutions
advanced_patterns.key_clues: Different solution types, various implementation approaches

content.heading: Cross-Text Connection Excellence
key_points: Analyze relationships between texts, not just individual text content
Look for agreement, disagreement, complementary perspectives, or building ideas
Consider different types of evidence and approaches authors use
Recognize that texts can partially agree while differing on specific aspects
content.strategy_reminder: Remember CONNECT: Compare topics, Outline positions, Notice agreements/disagreements, Note evidence types, Evaluate relationships, Choose best answer, Test against both texts
content.college_board_insight: Cross-text questions reward nuanced understanding of how authors relate to each other's ideas, not black-and-white agreement/disagreement.

content.message: Outstanding! You've mastered the art of cross-text analysis.

slides.title: Cross-Text Quick Check
slides.question: Passage 1 argues that urban gardens increase property values by 10% and reduce crime. Passage 2 discusses how urban gardens build community connections and provide fresh food access. How do these passages relate?
options: Passage 2 contradicts Passage 1's claims about urban gardens
Passage 2 provides different evidence supporting the overall benefits of urban gardens
Passage 2 proves that Passage 1's data about property values is incorrect
The passages discuss completely unrelated aspects of urban gardens
slides.explanation: Both passages support urban gardens' benefits but focus on different advantages: Passage 1 emphasizes economic/safety benefits while Passage 2 emphasizes social/health benefits. They complement rather than contradict each other.

strategy_card.title: Cross-Text Connections Quick Reference
steps: 1. COMPARE: Identify main topic and purpose of each text
3. NOTICE: Look for agreements and disagreements
7. TEST: Verify answer against both texts
tips: Focus on relationships between texts, not just individual content
Look for agreement, disagreement, complementary, or building patterns
Consider partial agreement with specific differences
Note different types of evidence and approaches used

common_mistakes: Analyzing each text separately instead of their relationship
Seeing only complete agreement or complete disagreement
Missing complementary relationships where texts discuss different aspects
Ignoring how one text might build upon or qualify another's claims
